docs.lead_paragraph: Tara Parker-Pope is the creator and writer of Well, a daily health blog and weekly column for The New York Times. She wrote this week's cover article, "The Fat Trap."

headline.main: Behind the Cover Story: Tara Parker-Pope on Weight Loss

docs.abstract: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.
docs.snippet: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.

docs.lead_paragraph: Grating the turnips for this flavorful flat omelet ensures they’ll be very tender.

headline.seo: Frittata With Turnips and Olives — Recipes for Health

docs.snippet: Grating the turnips for this flavorful flat omelet ensures they’ll be very tender.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the French term délestage is used to describe power cutoffs, but when applied to food shortages, it illustrates a stark reality.

headline.seo: In Congolese Capital, ‘Power Cut’ Applies to Food
headline.main: For Congo Children, Food Today Means None Tomorrow
headline.print_headline: For Congo Children, Food Today Means None Tomorrow

docs.abstract: Margin of survival for the people of the Democratic Republic of Congo is so slim that the the word 'delestage,' French term used for rolling power blackouts, is used to describe the availability of food as well as electricity; most people in Kinshasa, including children, eat only every other day, and the International Food Policy Research Institute reports that half of the country is considered undernourished.
docs.snippet: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the French term délestage is used to describe power cutoffs, but when applied to food shortages, it illustrates a stark reality.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study has found that the protocol of meting out meals with caution to people hospitalized with anorexia does not work.

headline.seo: Hospital Treatment for Anorexia Is Questioned
headline.main: Protocol to Treat Anorexia Is Faulted
headline.print_headline: Protocol To Treat Anorexia Is Faulted

docs.abstract: Some researchers and health providers are starting to question standard practice for feeding teenaged anorexic hospital patients, which involves starting with very small amounts of food and working up to incrementally larger meals; study published in The Journal of Adolescent Health found majority of anorexic patients suffered further weight loss during early part of regiment.
docs.snippet: A study has found that the protocol of meting out meals with caution to people hospitalized with anorexia does not work.

docs.lead_paragraph: Higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B, vitamin C, vitamin D and vitamin E are associated with better mental functioning in the elderly, a study shows.

headline.seo: Vitamins B, C, D and E and Omega-3 Strengthen Older Brains
headline.main: Nutrition: 4 Vitamins That Strengthen Older Brains
headline.print_headline: Nutrition: 4 Vitamins That Strengthen Older Brains

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Neurology finds that higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids, and of nutrients vitamin B, vitamin C, vitamin D and vitamin E are associated with better mental functioning in the elderly; Gene L Bowman of Oregon Health and Science University is study's lead author.
docs.snippet: Higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B, vitamin C, vitamin D and vitamin E are associated with better mental functioning in the elderly, a study shows.

docs.lead_paragraph: Urine has a uniquely valuable role in medicine: It holds clues not just to what people eat and drink, but also to how well their bodies are functioning.

headline.seo: A Valuable Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine
headline.main: A Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine
headline.print_headline: A Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on the various medical uses of urine, which can give clues about dietary health and organ function.
docs.snippet: Urine has a uniquely valuable role in medicine: It holds clues not just to what people eat and drink, but also to how well their bodies are functioning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hardy and reliable in the winter months, turnips are a logical foundation for comforting stews and gratins, but they’re also at home in egg or noodle dishes.

headline.seo: Turnips: Versatile and Nutritious in Any Season — Turnips: Versatile and Nutritious in Any Season
headline.main: Turnips: Versatile and Nutritious in Any Season

docs.snippet: Hardy and reliable in the winter months, turnips are a logical foundation for comforting stews and gratins, but they’re also at home in egg or noodle dishes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.

headline.seo: New Year’s Resolutions, Recycled, Are a Boon for Business
headline.main: Your Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business
headline.print_headline: I Just Got Here, But I Know Trouble When I See It: Those Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business

docs.abstract: Self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry; Americans were projected to spend $62 billion in 2011 on self-improvement in the hope of keeping resolutions; some stop-smoking and weight-loss programs, as well as gyms, are trying to help for the long haul, a strategy that can improve customers' chances of success and build brand loyalty and revenue.
docs.snippet: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many on-site cafes, geared to serve fitness-conscious exercisers with choices like vegetarian and gluten-free cuisine, are open to nonmembers, too.

headline.seo: Cafes at Health Clubs Stress Eating Right
headline.main: At the Gym Site, Food for Fitness Lovers
headline.kicker: New Jersey Dining | Health Club Cafes
headline.print_headline: At the Gym Site, Food For Fitness Lovers
headline.content_kicker: New Jersey Dining | Health Club Cafes

docs.abstract: Kelly Feeney reviews restaurants located at several health clubs in New Jersey.
docs.snippet: Many on-site cafes, geared to serve fitness-conscious exercisers with choices like vegetarian and gluten-free cuisine, are open to nonmembers, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: You can watch “The Biggest Loser” on television. Or you can live it, at a resort where guests are prodded and pushed and left panting.

headline.seo: My Week at the Biggest Loser Fat Camp
headline.main: My Week at the Biggest Loser Fat Camp

docs.abstract: Jennifer Conlin travel article on The Biggest Loser Resort at Fitness Ridge, in Ivins, Utah; in the style of the television program The Biggest Loser, guests are pushed and prodded in exercise activities and lectures in effort to shed weight.
docs.snippet: You can watch “The Biggest Loser” on television. Or you can live it, at a resort where guests are prodded and pushed and left panting.
